title: Transcending Compliance in the Financial Sector: The Impact of Negotiated Prosecutions on Enforcement Capacity and Corporate Accountability
abstractText: Negotiated prosecutions between corporations and the Dept of Justice and the SEC have increased dramatically since 2002, not co-incidentally the year of the passage of Sarbanes-Oxley. There are clear advantages to this process from the regulatory perspective - an admission of wrongdoing, court enforcement, addressing of deficiencies and acceptance of external monitoring. From the corporate perspective there is a shield in place against further action and on-going negative publicity. The research seeks to demonstrate how and why this mechanism developed. It looks at how it has impacted on corporate governance reform, organizational structure and the theoretical underpinnings of corporate law. Further the research seeks to examine the appropriate parameters of this sort of device.
findingsText:
The primary purpose of this funding was to find out more about how the deferred prosecution system for violation of SEC rules was being used in the US and explore its potential.
The system has now been adopted in the UK as part of the bribery legislation. Government seems to have ruled out further adoption of deferred prosecution but given its desire to change "banking forever" in both cultural and business practice terms it would do well to think of this again.
